awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research (RUI): Search for Exotic Transient Spin-dependent Signals from Ultralight Dark Matter Fields
awd_abstract_narration:
A host of astrophysical and cosmological measurements have conclusively established that over 85% of all matter in the Universe is dark matter. Understanding the nature of dark matter is one of the greatest challenges of modern physics and is of paramount importance in understanding the origin and structure of the universe. A theoretically well-motivated possibility is that the dark matter consists of ultralight fields, corresponding to particles of very low mass. The mass-energy associated with dark matter is then primarily stored in oscillations of the dark matter field or in localized defects. If the dark matter takes this form, then instead of being bathed in a uniform dark matter flux, terrestrial detectors will witness transient events when the Earth passes through a dark matter clump or a kind of domain wall such as is found in a magnetized material such as nickel. This award provides support to operate, expand, and significantly upgrade a network of geographically separated, time-synchronized atomic magnetometers to search for correlated transient signals heralding new physics.

Both institutions have a strong history of diversity, with CSU - East Bay being the most diverse university in the continental United States and Oberlin College being the first college to admit African American students and women in a co-educational setting on a regular basis. The proposed research programs are at the vanguard of attracting and retaining women and underrepresented minority physicists.

The Global Network of Optical Magnetometers to search for Exotic physics (GNOME) is sensitive to nuclear and electron spin couplings to various exotic particles and fields. To date, no such search for transient spin-dependent interactions has ever been carried out, making the proposed research a completely novel experimental window on new physics. In addition to carrying out a dedicated long-term search using the existing GNOME during the first year of the grant, the GNOME will be upgraded in order to dramatically improve its sensitivity.

por.por_cntn:
A host of astrophysical and cosmological measurements suggest that the majority of matter in the Universe is an invisible substance we term "dark matter." Understanding its nature is of paramount importance to astrophysics, cosmology, and particle physics. A well-motivated possibility is that dark matter consists of bosonic fields composed of ultralight particles such as axions or hidden photons that can generate signals measurable with atomic magnetometers.

In this research Cal State East Bay led an international collaboration of both research universities and undergraduate institutions to operate, expand, and upgrade a worldwide network of time synchronized atomic magnetometers to search for correlated signals from ultralight bosonic dark matter fields or other exotic new physics. The Global Network of Optical Magnetometers for Exotic physics searches (GNOME) is an array of more than a dozen optical atomic magnetometers inside multi-layer shielding systems, with stations in Europe, North America, Asia, the Middle East, and Australia. The GNOME is being used to search for large compact composite dark matter objects, stochastic fluctuations of dark matter fields, and bursts of exotic low-mass fields (ELFs) from cataclysmic astrophysical events (like black hole mergers).

An important component of this project has been the development of new experimental techniques to search for spin-dependent interactions. An exciting new direction emerging from this research is the development of levitated ferromagnetic torque sensors. Under conditions where the total angular momentum of a ferromagnet is dominated by its intrinsic spin, the ferromagnet is predicted to behave as a gyroscope. If such a ferromagnetic gyroscope (FG) can be sufficiently isolated from the environment, it has the potential to measure spin-dependent interactions with a sensitivity far surpassing that of other systems. The high sensitivity is the result of rapid averaging of quantum noise. We have analyzed the sensitivity and applications of levitated ferromagnetic torque sensors to precision measurements testing the laws of physics, including probing the intersection between quantum mechanics and general relativity by measuring relativistic frame dragging (the Lense-Thirring effect) with intrinsic spin.

We also discovered that the Earth itself acts as a transducer for hidden-photon dark matter to generate real global magnetic field patterns, enabling searches for hidden photon dark matter with networks of unshielded magnetometers. We carried out a search for such hidden-photon dark matter using an existing dataset from a global array of magnetometers used primarily for studying geophysical magnetic fields.

Numerous undergraduate students have worked on the research project during this period. The students have played major roles in construction, setup, maintenance, and repair of the experimental apparatus, data collection, data analysis, and design of new experimental apparatuses. Our research program plays an especially important role in broadening access to undergraduate physics research: because Cal State East Bay is one of the most diverse undergraduate institutions in the country -- being both a Hispanic-Serving Institution (HSI) and an Asian American and Native American Pacific Islander-Serving Institution (AANAPISI), as well as having the third highest enrollment of African American students in the California State University system -- we have attracted new physics majors from a diverse pool of native students who otherwise would not have such an opportunity. The majority of the students who have worked in our laboratory have been underserved minority students. Our experiments are ideally suited for mentorship of undergraduate students, since, in spite of their potential impact on our understanding of fundamental interactions, they are small scale and students have been involved in all aspects of the work from planning, design, and construction of the apparatus to data acquisition and analysis. Numerous students have presented talks or posters at regional/national meetings and the majority of students have coauthored peer-reviewed publications.

Our program has provided numerous, diverse undergraduate students the opportunity to directly experience first-hand the excitement of cutting-edge research.
